clues: This city is home to the world's tallest brick minaret.
The capital of a country known for its diverse culture and history.
fun_fact: Delhi has the world's largest spice market, Khari Baoli, which has existed since the 17th century!
The Lotus Temple in Delhi is one of the few Bahá'í Houses of Worship in the world.
trivia: The Red Fort in Delhi was once home to the famous Peacock Throne of the Mughal emperors.
Connaught Place, a major shopping hub, was inspired by Royal Crescent in Bath, England.

clues: This city is home to Bollywood, the world’s largest film industry.
It was originally a group of seven islands before land reclamation merged them together.
fun_fact: Mumbai’s Dabbawalas deliver over 200,000 lunchboxes daily with an incredible 99.99% accuracy!
The Gateway of India was built to commemorate King George V’s visit in 1911.
trivia: Mumbai’s local trains carry more passengers daily than the entire population of Australia!
The Bandra-Worli Sea Link has steel wires equal to the circumference of Earth.

clues: This city has a clock tower that is often mistaken for its bell.
It has the world’s oldest underground railway system.
fun_fact: Big Ben is actually the name of the bell, not the tower!
London’s buses weren’t always red—they were color-coded for different routes until 1907.
trivia: The London Eye can carry up to 800 passengers per rotation.
More than 300 languages are spoken in London, making it one of the most linguistically diverse cities in the world.

clues: Home to one of the Seven Wonders of the Modern World, a towering Christ statue.
Famous for its colorful Carnival and samba music.
fun_fact: Rio's Copacabana Beach has a black-and-white wave-patterned pavement inspired by Portuguese designs.
The name ‘Rio de Janeiro’ means ‘January River’ in Portuguese, but there is no river there!
trivia: The Christ the Redeemer statue was struck by lightning in 2014 and lost a finger!
Sugarloaf Mountain got its name because it resembles a traditional shape of sugarloaves used in the 16th century.
